title: Venture capital fundraising – Both sides of the story

author: Matej Zalar, Visionect d.o.o.
Rok Habinc, S. T. HAMMER d.o.o.

segmentation: Hello.
My name is Martha Zara, messier than the founder of a company called Vision Act with me is Robbins.
He's a general partner at the Esther Hammer, it's.
Actually, the company that owns the SDH Ventures the company that invested some capital into our company.
How many of you are familiar with the with the venture capital?
Whew, OK, so here today we are about to present the both sides.
Up the story how an investor looks under his investments and how fundraiser or a founder is actually searching for the investment for the investor.
So briefly, about STH Ventures was founded in 2010.
Represented and run by Estee Hammer Slovene company.
Investors in the fund are 51% private, 49% Republic of Slovenia VC.
Fund size is 7 1/2 million euros.
Geographical focus at least 70% of the investments will be in Slovenia.
We think we'll make between 6:00 and 8:00 investments in the range of about half a million to 1 1/2 million.
There's no sector limitations.
Basically, we can invest in will invest in many industries.
There are few that we can't like weapons manufacturing, but.
There's that's profitable, but not for us.
Currently we have two investments, so vision it was the second one that we made.
OK, in a few words about the Vision Act, we founded our company in 2007 and started developing tablet devices for enterprise environments such as hotels, restaurants, hospitals, museums and so on.
This is the tablet device that we already developed when we started.
We figured it will have, uh, this is this is going to be a long and expensive process.
So we started bootstrappers wrapping our company, which means that we did a lot of R&D projects for other companies that needed our know how in electronics and software development.
Now during this process we finished about 30 of this R&D projects.

We also got around 11. International awards for a tablet device that works for months without recharge that so robust that you can wash it in a washing machine and also has their own buttons so it's only touch operated, not even on, off, or reset anything so.
Now today we're development partners with Epson and Ink.
We're already selling our devices throughout the world, and recently this year we also got backed up by venture capital.
So a little bit about the investment process.
How does it work?
VC being the new superhero of the modern world, providing an opportunity for many aspiring companies to to make it in the world and to become larger than they would without the inflow of cash.
How does the investment process work?
There is a deal flow generation.
We have our feelers out there, a lot of companies come to present ourselves.
We meet.
We present ourselves at conferences like this one at conferences meant for enterpreneurs.
Leads come through Internet, so there's there's various channels through which we get our our potential candidates or proposals.
We do the first deal screening.
So basically we want to understand what is the project or what is the proposal about.
What's the idea?
What pain does it solve?
Is there a market for it?
Do we understand the market?
Their financials that are.
Backing this idea, is there a team or is it the one person or as a team, well balanced?
There's this bunch of questions that we ask ourselves in our screening process.
The key?
The key point here usually being the team.
There are many good ideas out there and there are not so many good teams out there which are able to execute whatever they've written in their business plan.
I often say that there's not a single business plan is execute as it was written.
Basically, you write it today, tomorrow.
It's obsolete tomorrow.
The world has changed and the business plan is not going to revolve.
It's not going to be executed as it was written.
However, we need to believe that there's a team standing behind this business plan who can sail this boat around the whatever it will meet.
And there's a team that will that will together with us with our assistance, guide it to some safe shores at the end.
If we come through the deal screening, if both our team and of course the team on the side of the of the company that we would invest in agree.
On basic ideas we go through on basic.
Obstacles or basic shape of the transaction we go through due diligence process.
In this case this is smaller due diligence.
Then it will be with an older well established company, because usually these companies that we invest in our younger they were five years old.
But this is old in terms of in terms of VC funding.
Usually it may sometimes be only an idea or it may be a company that's few months or a couple of years old whereby there's there are less closets in which there are less.
Potential obstacles hidden.
That's the due diligence is to assure that there are none.
No dead bodies in the causes that would fall out later.
When an investment decision is made.
On the investment board again, these factors that have mentioned earlier are considered business plan financials.
The team, the proposed project proposed service.
Will it work?
We structured transaction together with the with the team or with the intrapreneurs.
What's the share?
In what terms is it going to be as an equity stake is going to be some in loan?
What type of involvement?
How long is our involvement or the possible exits?
ETC etc.
We do the transaction and then post transaction.
Of course we manage.
The our our investment.
We work closely with the with the firm that we've invested into.
We help a lot, specially in the in the early days.
We put our people on boards or on advisory committees within these companies so that we can, with our knowledge with our network, help them do better.
Whatever it is that they do.
And of course, at the end of the whole process in 46 years we will exit that we're not.
We're not married to the project for more than four six years, and then we need to exit.
So we need to start considering the exit options strategies before entering even.
We need to see that there is a way out for a fund for investor at the end of the story.
OK, now how the whole process looked on our side, what we had to go through.
First of all.
We made a lot of mistakes here when while we were fund raising and the biggest mistake was you have to understand the whole process, which means that you are selling.
You're selling your project to a potential investor.
Before you know that the sooner you can start planning.
Your sales.
Another thing is there is no such thing as getting funded in one month.
I see a lot of young entrepreneurs doing this mistake.
They need the money they go to investors and they think they're going to get funded in one month.
The thing is, you need to develop a relationship and trust and believe word and this does not come from 145 minute pitch.
You give to an investor, but it's a long process.
It takes time, so usually investments, at least the bigger ones will take from 6 to 9 months.
At least or even more.
So if you don't know that it can be very frustrating.
So the second step is you have to know when you're ready, because business ideas only usually do not get funded.
I mean usually because if you are not a serial entrepreneur with outstanding track record, you will not get funded based on your idea.
The at least what you need is a prototype.
Even better if you have your first customers.
I would advise that if you have your first customers at that time, you're ready to go out and start.
Looking for an investment?
Before that?
You're wasting probably wasting your time and your investors time.
Next step.
Is you need to identify relevant VCs, which means that.
Are they in your industry and in your region?
'cause usually investors do not invest in companies far away from them because it's.
I if they do that, usually hard to manage this companies so get to know these things you need to do your homework actually.
You need to prepare the documentation.
The first document that you need is called the deck.
It's about 10.
Pages long 10 slides PowerPoint presentation that you start sending via email to potential investors.
The first thing you do you do not send business plan, discuss.
Venture capitalists usually don't read business plans 'cause they're just too long and boring, and especially if you get a couple of dozen business plans per week.

It can be quite boring, so the deck after that when you get the feedback that they are interested, you send them executive summary which is a short two to three pages where you describe your business idea.
And after that, if you get the feedback again that they are still interested, they want to know more.
You send them your business plan which hopefully hopefully is not longer than 20 pages.
Then you approach to relevant thesis.
As in any sale sales process, you need to talk.
You want to talk to decision makers in Venture Capital War.
These are the general partners you want to talk to so.
When you successfully approached them then you get the opportunity opportunity to do the pitch.
Here again, you have to know exactly what you're talking about, so it means you have to.
Prepare and train and train and train and when you come to the investor you need to know what you have to talk about.
There is a lot of this on the Internet so I'm not going to bore you with that.
But as it looks at team is the most important one.
You need to present the team efficiently.
Then the market the pain you're solving, your financials, business model and so on.
After that for me, what I saw is very, very important point.
This is further meetings and updates after your successful pitch you need to update your investors and about your progress.
The progress you're doing every two to three weeks for the next few following months.
So it's a long process again and after that you're probably.
If you're successful, you got the term shit before you sign it.
You have to negotiate it.
The problem with the term sheet is 'cause there's whole lot of terms and terminology or not familiar with plus 'cause you're a young company not yet selling your product.
Usually it's hard to figure out what the what the market value of your company actually is.
So the best thing here is to get a couple of term sheets from different investors.
If you're lucky enough so.
Based on that, you get a strong, stronger negotiating position that works well.
Do you signed the term sheet?
You got to do the due diligence which already Rock talked about after the successful due diligence you signed the deal.
Get the money and the fun starts so.
Short
It's the whole process.
And that's pretty much what we prepared, but open to questions.
This was fascinating to me and perfect timing.
I'm involved in a program with Stanford University where they have a lot of startup companies and I'm counseling them on data protection, but they're also asking for advice on just this topic and.
Do you have any advice for people who are just starting down this path?
Very bright people with great ideas who are trying to eventually get venture capitalists to fund them.
I think your list of topics was very very good, but when they're just starting on this path and you just have a group of really inexperienced but very bright people with a wonderful idea that.
We've actually taken their idea to.
These are all health information technology companies and we've gone too.
CEOs of hospitals that are I know or that are my clients already and ask them, what do you think of this?
And they say, well, this sounds great, you know, let's see more.
So how do you get from from that step to where you are now?
Yeah.

Basic advice would be don't approach the VCs too early, so unless you are as as Meta said, unless you are Siri Intrapreneur with track record then perhaps you'll get funded on any idea, but these occasions are fewer and very far between.
If you're a young, start up with no track record, you gotta bootstrap yourself for awhile.
I mean you gotta get to the step where you have something to show for.
Favorably a client that's that's a great, but at least proof of concept you need to get there and you can get there with some other means of financing before coming to the VC world.
I mean, there Angel.
Financing out there there's.
There's crowdsourcing.
There's there's a bunch of types of financing where you can get smaller amounts of money for less commitment.
Of course, that will get you through the first few months that you need the time to develop your idea and to develop the product and those service you will be offering.
Don't start with VCs too soon because Mattie said even in a smaller environment like Slovenia, we get lots of proposals and so you.
You risk of being rejected just because you're not ready.
Do your homework seldom will you get the second chance.
But there's plenty of money out there chasing good projects.
So don't be afraid, just just go for it.
Don't be afraid to fail.
Because failure in a VC world is not seen as something negative.
Actually seen as as an experience that somebody is bringing along and knows how to deal with failure and pick themselves up.
So just go for it and bootstrap yourself as much as you can so search for sources of funding or financing and force be very.
You know?
You're going to be running on a tight budget, so you get it.
You gotta not spend money where it's not necessary to spend.
Seek for the three F's friends, fools and family who may get you through the first few months that you need to get to a stage where you will be ready to start talking to some serious investors.
